newsitem.title: ALBANIA: Vranitzky says Albanians must compromise on vote.
newsitem.headline: Vranitzky says Albanians must compromise on vote.

text.p: European envoy Franz Vranitzky urged Albanian politicians to compromise over crucial elections on Friday as he ended another mission to the Balkan state without winning their agreement.
Early elections were agreed in March to halt rioting and violence after thousands of Albanians lost their life-savings in the collapse of pyramid investment schemes.
But the polls were thrown into jeopardy as some parties accused President Sali Berisha's Democratic Party of tilting the rules in its favour.
Vranitzky late on Thursday seemed to have brokered a fresh deal to get the elections back on track but most political parties later said they were again considering boycotting the poll.

"This is the reason that political dialogue in this country must continue," former Austrian chancellor Vranitzky, on his fifth mission to bring calm to the former Stalinist state, told a news conference.
Although much calmer, Albania still sees violence and shootings every day and the whole country is subject to a curfew from nine in the evening to five in the morning.
The Socialists, Albania's second-largest party, remain deeply distrustful of Berisha and his right-wing former ruling party.
They said a new election law, passed in the early hours of Friday after Vranitzky persuaded politicians to amend it, was not still not acceptable.
"We are unhappy with the passage of this law," said Naim Dokle, chairman of the Socialist Party parliamentary group. "Now we are trying to talk with other parties."

The Socialists are part of a nine-party national unity government that was installed to stem the unrest. They and others want more electoral seats allocated on a proportional basis, while the Democratic Party wants more majority voting.
The Socialists pulled out of the last elections in May 1996, which international observers said were flawed.
Vranitzky, a special envoy of the Organisation for Security and Cooperation in Europe (OSCE), said he did not think the planned election date of June 29 should be postponed.
His spokeswoman said the OSCE still planned to prepare to monitor the elections, vital for them to be considered free and fair in international eyes.
"We hope they will come to some sort of solution very soon," the spokeswoman told journalists.
"We are ready for the monitoring and we just hope that all the political parties will be on board," she added.
Vranitzky again warned that the international community was closely watching Albania.
"Albanian politicians must be aware of the fact that the international community may reconsider its preparedness to offer assistance," he said.
Italy, leader of a multi-national military force to safeguard aid supplies to Albania, has said the troops may leave if the deal on early elections falls apart.
